Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Commercial Energy Management Technology (CEM-Tech) is a three-year project to develop a certificate and an Associates of Applied Science (AAS) degree program whose aim is to address a nationwide shortage of trained building technicians and training programs in the commercial energy management area. This is particularly important in the areas of building automation, commercial energy auditing, building commissioning and retro-commissioning. This shortage is bound to become more acute over the next few years as current HVAC technicians in the commercial and industrial fields start reaching retirement age, and as the field of building construction advances and grows. Raritan Valley Community College's CEM-Tech program aims to develop curricula and student experiences that will help to meet this shortage. This will be done working closely with industry experts. The goal is preparing students and incumbent workers in Sustainable Building Operations.

Raritan Valley Community College will work to develop an industry-aligned curriculum following rigorous academic standards, a campus as a living laboratory model, and strengthening core curriculum for general education. The end product being a Certificate and an AAS degree in Commercial Energy Management Technology. Industry partners and like-minded community and four-year colleges have been invited to join in a collaborative effort where curriculum-development best practices and the sharing of resources will be emphasized. A portfolio of stand-alone seminars with stackable credentials will be developed for both facilities managers and incumbent workers. Transfer pathways will also be developed for high school students, incumbent workers, and managers. A special focus will be placed on developing strategies to reach minorities and under-represented populations. Following the recommendation of industry partner, new laboratories will be equipped with state-of-the-art hardware, software, and instrumentation that is relevant in the field. The outputs of this effort will be available for nationwide dissemination and sharing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CEM-Tech was a three-year NSF-Funded project whose ongoing aim is to address a deficiency identified by government and industry, which is a severe nationwide shortage of trained building technicians and training programs in the Commercial Energy Management area, specifically in the fields of Building Automation, Commercial Energy Auditing, Building Commissioning and Retro-Commissioning.  This shortage is bound to become even more acute over the next few years as the current cadre of HVAC building technicians in the commercial and industrial fields start reaching retirement age, and as new building construction continues together with normal business expansion for existing buildings.  Our objective was the development and implementation of a technically sound program having academic rigor, where industry experts participated together with academia, advising and cooperating in the development of courses and associated learning goals. Synergistic engagement of this kind between Industry and Academia not only that has the beneficial short-term impact of helping alleviate the present shortage of skilled professionals, but also translates into medium-and long-term benefits, starting with achieving more efficient operation of the various building systems, bringing together a reduction of fuel consumption and carbon emissions, and augmenting comfort while improving the bottom line of building stakeholders.  The beneficial effects will not only be felt by building occupants and managers/owners, they are also in our best national interest as fuel consumption and carbon emissions shall be reduced.   RVCC?s CEM-Tech program is currently spearheading this effort.

In order to successfully reap the benefits mentioned above, which we set for ourselves with this project, Raritan Valley Community College developed Industry-aligned curriculum towards a Certificate and an AAS degree in the field of Commercial Energy Management Technology, following rigorous academic standards and the Campus as a Living Laboratory model. We also strengthened core curriculum for general education.  The ongoing goal is to prepare students and incumbent workers in Sustainable Building Operations.  Industry partners and like-minded community and four-year colleges were invited to join in a collaborative effort where curriculum-development best practices and the sharing of resources were emphasized.  A portfolio of stand-alone seminars with stackable credentials was also developed, with facilities managers and incumbent workers in mind. Transfer pathways have been sought after, for high school students, incumbent workers and managers, with especial focus on developing strategies to reach minorities and under-represented populations.  New state-of-the-art laboratories have been built and are now fully equipped with the most modern hardware, software and instrumentation used in the field, following the recommendations given by our industry partners.  The fruits of this effort are now available for nationwide dissemination and sharing.

The following is a summary of the main goals achieved by Project CEM-Tech:

Goal-1: To Develop Industry-aligned Curriculum and Innovations in Active Learning.

Goal-2: To Build Institutional Capacity for High Quality Instruction Through Facilities Development and Recruitment and Professional Development for Faculty Teaching in the Areas of Commercial Energy Management.

Goal-3: To Target Community Outreach and Student Support Resulting in Increased Student Enrollment in the AAS-Degree and Certificate Programs, Including Women and Other Underrepresented Students.
